The implementation does not distinguish between public and private user data - it returns the same structure as get_current_user_profile.\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n<details class=\\\"tool\\\">\\n<summary>get_user_top_artists_and_tracks</summary>\\n\\nRetrieves the current user's most listened to artists or tracks based on their listening history over different time periods.\\n\\n**Parameters:**\\n\\u2022 `type` (required): Either \\\"artists\\\" or \\\"tracks\\\" to specify what to retrieve\\n\\u2022 `limit` (optional): Maximum items to return (1-50, default 20)\\n\\u2022 `offset` (optional): Starting index for pagination (default 0)\\n\\u2022 `time_range` (optional): Time period - \\\"short_term\\\" (last 4 weeks), \\\"medium_term\\\" (last 6 months, default), or \\\"long_term\\\" (several years)\\n\\n**Usage Examples:**\\n- Show user's favorite artists: `type=\\\"artists\\\", limit=10`\\n- Display top tracks over long period: `type=\\\"tracks\\\", time_range=\\\"long_term\\\"`\\n- Paginate through results: `type=\\\"artists\\\", limit=20, offset=20`\\n\\n**Returns:** Object with items array (full artist or track objects), total count, limit, and offset for pagination.\\n\\n**Behavior Notes:** Data is based on the user's listening history stored in `top_artists` and `top_tracks` collections in the database. Returns empty items array if user has no listening history for the specified type.\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n<details class=\\\"tool\\\">\\n<summary>get_album</summary>\\n\\nRetrieves detailed information about a single album including metadata, artists, tracks, and availability.\\n\\n**Parameters:**\\n\\u2022 `album_id` (required): The Spotify album ID (e.g., \\\"4kBp5iVByDSAUc0lb78jCZ\\\")\\n\\u2022 `market` (optional): ISO 3166-1 alpha-2 country code to check availability (e.g., \\\"US\\\", \\\"CA\\\")\\n\\n**Prerequisites:** Album ID can be obtained from e.g. search_for_item, get_artists_albums, or get_users_saved_albums.\\n\\n**Usage Examples:**\\n- Get full album details: `album_id=\\\"4kBp5iVByDSAUc0lb78jCZ\\\"`\\n- Check album availability in market: `album_id=\\\"4kBp5iVByDSAUc0lb78jCZ\\\", market=\\\"US\\\"`\\n\\n**Returns:** Complete album object.\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n<details class=\\\"tool\\\">\\n<summary>get_several_albums</summary>\\n\\nEfficiently retrieves information for multiple albums in a single request, useful for batch operations.\\n\\n**Parameters:**\\n\\u2022 `album_ids` (required): Array of Spotify album IDs (maximum 20)\\n\\u2022 `market` (optional): ISO 3166-1 alpha-2 country code for availability filtering\\n\\n**Prerequisites:** Album IDs can be obtained from e.g. search_for_item, get_artists_albums, or get_users_saved_albums.\\n\\n**Usage Examples:**\\n- Get multiple albums: `album_ids=[\\\"4kBp5iVByDSAUc0lb78jCZ\\\", \\\"gJIfNlJdPASNffy7UY2V6D\\\"]`\\n- Batch fetch with market filter: `album_ids=[...], market=\\\"US\\\"`\\n\\n**Returns:** Object with albums array containing full album objects in the same order as requested IDs.\\n\\n**Behavior Notes:** More efficient than making individual get_album calls. Maximum 20 albums per request. Invalid or non-existent IDs return null in their position in the array.\\n\\n**Agent-Facing Tool Notes:**\\n> \\\"More efficient than making individual `get_album` calls. Use this function when you need information about multiple albums.\\\"\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n<details class=\\\"tool\\\">\\n<summary>get_album_tracks</summary>\\n\\nRetrieves the track listing for a specific album with pagination support.\\n\\n**Parameters:**\\n\\u2022 `album_id` (required): The Spotify album ID\\n\\u2022 `market` (optional): ISO 3166-1 alpha-2 country code\\n\\u2022 `limit` (optional): Maximum tracks to return (1-50, default 20)\\n\\u2022 `offset` (optional): Starting index (default 0)\\n\\n**Prerequisites:** Album ID can be obtained from e.g. search_for_item, get_artists_albums, or get_users_saved_albums.\\n\\n**Usage Examples:**\\n- Get first 10 tracks: `album_id=\\\"4kBp5iVByDSAUc0lb78jCZ\\\", limit=10`\\n- Paginate through tracks: `album_id=\\\"4kBp5iVByDSAUc0lb78jCZ\\\", offset=20, limit=20`\\n\\n**Returns:** Object with items array (track objects), total track count, limit, and offset.\\n\\n**Behavior Notes:** Useful for albums with many tracks where you don't need to fetch the full album object. Tracks include album reference and full metadata.\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n<details class=\\\"tool\\\">\\n<summary>get_users_saved_albums</summary>\\n\\nRetrieves all albums saved to the current user's library with timestamps for when the user saved each one.\\n\\n**Parameters:**\\n\\u2022 `limit` (optional): Maximum albums to return (1-50, default 20)\\n\\u2022 `offset` (optional): Starting index (default 0)\\n\\u2022 `market` (optional): ISO 3166-1 alpha-2 country code\\n\\n**Usage Examples:**\\n- Get all saved albums: Paginate with increasing offset until total reached\\n- Filter by market: `market=\\\"US\\\"`\\n\\n**Returns:** Object with items array (each item contains added_at timestamp and full album object), total saved count, limit, and offset.\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n<details class=\\\"tool\\\">\\n<summary>check_users_saved_albums</summary>\\n\\nChecks if one or more albums are saved in the current user's library without fetching full album data.\\n\\n**Parameters:**\\n\\u2022 `album_ids` (required): Array of album IDs to check (maximum 50)\\n\\n**Usage Examples:**\\n- Check single album: `album_ids=[\\\"4kBp5iVByDSAUc0lb78jCZ\\\"]`\\n- Batch check multiple: `album_ids=[\\\"4kBp5iVByDSAUc0lb78jCZ\\\", \\\"gJIfNlJdPASNffy7UY2V6D\\\", \\\"5V17F52VsJ3ZDIF1iYxe6D\\\"]`\\n\\n**Returns:** Array of booleans in same order as input album IDs, where true means saved and false means not saved.\\n\\n**Behavior Notes:** Very efficient for checking save status without retrieving full album data. Maximum 50 IDs per request.\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n<details class=\\\"tool\\\">\\n<summary>get_artist</summary>\\n\\nRetrieves comprehensive information about a single artist including genres, popularity, and follower count.\\n\\n**Parameters:**\\n\\u2022 `artist_id` (required): The Spotify artist ID (e.g., \\\"W0e71GNltAWtwmOaMZcm1J\\\")\\n\\n**Prerequisites:** Artist ID can be obtained from e.g. get_album (artists field), search_for_item, or get_artists_related_artists.\\n\\n**Usage Examples:**\\n- Get artist details: `artist_id=\\\"W0e71GNltAWtwmOaMZcm1J\\\"`\\n- Display artist profile page with genres and popularity\\n\\n**Returns:** Full artist object.\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n<details class=\\\"tool\\\">\\n<summary>get_several_artists</summary>\\n\\nEfficiently retrieves information for multiple artists in a single request.\\n\\n**Parameters:**\\n\\u2022 `artist_ids` (required): Array of Spotify artist IDs (maximum 50)\\n\\n**Prerequisites:** Artist IDs can be obtained from e.g. search_for_item, get_album (artists field), or get_artists_related_artists.\\n\\n**Usage Examples:**\\n- Batch fetch artists: `artist_ids=[\\\"W0e71GNltAWtwmOaMZcm1J\\\", \\\"DqJ4SeZM7iQuxSkKOdQvTB\\\"]`\\n- Get all artists from an album's artist list\\n\\n**Returns:** Object with artists array containing full artist objects in the same order as requested IDs.\\n\\n**Behavior Notes:** More efficient than individual get_artist calls. Maximum 50 artists per request.\\n\\n**Agent-Facing Tool Notes:**\\n> \\\"More efficient than making individual `get_artist` calls. Use this function when you need information about multiple artists.\\\"\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n<details class=\\\"tool\\\">\\n<summary>get_artists_albums</summary>\\n\\nRetrieves all albums by a specific artist with filtering and pagination support.\\n\\n**Parameters:**\\n\\u2022 `artist_id` (required): The Spotify artist ID\\n\\u2022 `include_groups` (optional): Comma-separated list to filter by type - \\\"album\\\", \\\"single\\\", \\\"appears_on\\\", \\\"compilation\\\"\\n\\u2022 `market` (optional): ISO 3166-1 alpha-2 country code\\n\\u2022 `limit` (optional): Maximum albums (1-50, default 20)\\n\\u2022 `offset` (optional): Starting index (default 0)\\n\\n**Prerequisites:** Artist ID can be obtained from e.g. search_for_item, get_album (artists field), or get_artists_related_artists.\\n\\n**Usage Examples:**\\n- Get all albums: `artist_id=\\\"W0e71GNltAWtwmOaMZcm1J\\\"`\\n- Filter albums only: `artist_id=\\\"W0e71GNltAWtwmOaMZcm1J\\\", include_groups=\\\"album\\\"`\\n- Get singles: `artist_id=\\\"W0e71GNltAWtwmOaMZcm1J\\\", include_groups=\\\"single\\\"`\\n\\n**Returns:** Object with items array containing full album objects, total count, limit, and offset.\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n<details class=\\\"tool\\\">\\n<summary>get_artists_top_tracks</summary>\\n\\nRetrieves an artist's most popular tracks in a specific market/country.\\n\\n**Parameters:**\\n\\u2022 `artist_id` (required): The Spotify artist ID\\n\\u2022 `market` (required): ISO 3166-1 alpha-2 country code (e.g., \\\"US\\\", \\\"GB\\\")\\n\\n**Prerequisites:** Artist ID can be obtained from e.g. get_album, search_for_item, or get_artists_related_artists. Market parameter is required as popularity varies by region.\\n\\n**Usage Examples:**\\n- Get US top tracks: `artist_id=\\\"W0e71GNltAWtwmOaMZcm1J\\\", market=\\\"US\\\"`\\n- Display artist's hit songs in user's country\\n\\n**Returns:** Object with tracks array containing up to 10 full track objects, sorted by popularity (highest first).\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n<details class=\\\"tool\\\">\\n<summary>get_artists_related_artists</summary>\\n\\nRetrieves artists similar to the specified artist based on genre overlap.\\n\\n**Parameters:**\\n\\u2022 `artist_id` (required): The Spotify artist ID\\n\\n**Prerequisites:** Artist ID can be obtained from e.g. get_album, search_for_item, or artists.\\n\\n**Usage Examples:**\\n- Find similar artists: `artist_id=\\\"W0e71GNltAWtwmOaMZcm1J\\\"`\\n\\n**Returns:** Object with artists array containing up to 20 full artist objects similar to the input artist.\\n\\n**Behavior Notes:**\\nReturns artists that share at least one genre with the input artist, sorted by popularity (highest first), limited to 20 results. Similarity is binary - any genre overlap qualifies an artist as related, regardless of how many genres are shared. An artist sharing 1 genre is treated the same as one sharing 5 genres; ranking is determined solely by popularity.\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n<details class=\\\"tool\\\">\\n<summary>get_playlist</summary>\\n\\nRetrieves complete information about a specific playlist including tracks, owner, and metadata.\\n\\n**Parameters:**\\n\\u2022 `playlist_id` (required): The Spotify playlist ID (e.g., \\\"QDyH69WryQ7dPRXVOFmy2V\\\")\\n\\u2022 `market` (optional): ISO 3166-1 alpha-2 country code\\n\\u2022 `fields` (optional): Comma-separated list of fields to return (filters response)\\n\\u2022 `additional_types` (optional): Comma-separated list - \\\"track\\\", \\\"episode\\\" (default is track only)\\n\\n**Prerequisites:** Playlist ID can be obtained from e.g. search_for_item, get_current_users_playlists, get_user_playlists, or get_category_playlists.\\n\\n**Usage Examples:**\\n- Get full playlist: `playlist_id=\\\"QDyH69WryQ7dPRXVOFmy2V\\\"`\\n- Filter specific fields: `playlist_id=\\\"QDyH69WryQ7dPRXVOFmy2V\\\", fields=\\\"name,owner,tracks.total\\\"`\\n\\n**Returns:** Complete playlist object with name, description, owner, public/collaborative flags, snapshot_id, tracks object with items array, images, and URLs.\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n<details class=\\\"tool\\\">\\n<summary>get_playlist_items</summary>\\n\\nRetrieves the track/episode items in a playlist with detailed metadata about when and by whom they were added.\\n\\n**Parameters:**\\n\\u2022 `playlist_id` (required): The Spotify playlist ID\\n\\u2022 `market` (optional): ISO 3166-1 alpha-2 country code\\n\\u2022 `fields` (optional): Comma-separated list of fields to filter response\\n\\u2022 `limit` (optional): Maximum items (1-50, default 20)\\n\\u2022 `offset` (optional): Starting index (default 0)\\n\\u2022 `additional_types` (optional): \\\"track\\\", \\\"episode\\\" or both\\n\\n**Prerequisites:** Playlist ID can be obtained from e.g. search_for_item, get_current_users_playlists, get_user_playlists, or get_category_playlists.\\n\\n**Usage Examples:**\\n- Get first 20 tracks: `playlist_id=\\\"QDyH69WryQ7dPRXVOFmy2V\\\", limit=20`\\n- Paginate through large playlist: `playlist_id=\\\"...\\\", offset=40, limit=20`\\n- Get only specific fields: `fields=\\\"items(added_at,track(name,artists))\\\"`\\n\\n**Returns:** Object with items array (each item has added_at, added_by, track, and is_local fields), total count, limit, and offset.\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n<details class=\\\"tool\\\">\\n<summary>get_current_users_playlists</summary>\\n\\nRetrieves playlists owned by the current authenticated user (does not include followed playlists).\\n\\n**Parameters:**\\n\\u2022 `limit` (optional): Maximum playlists (1-50, default 20)\\n\\u2022 `offset` (optional): Starting index (default 0)\\n\\n**Usage Examples:**\\n- List user's playlists: `limit=20`\\n- Get all playlists: Paginate until all fetched\\n\\n**Returns:** Object with items array (full playlist objects), total count, limit, and offset. Playlists are returned in the order they were first created.\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n<details class=\\\"tool\\\">\\n<summary>get_user_playlists</summary>\\n\\nRetrieves all public playlists owned by a specific user (not playlists they follow).\\n\\n**Parameters:**\\n\\u2022 `user_id` (required): The Spotify user ID\\n\\u2022 `limit` (optional): Maximum playlists (1-50, default 20)\\n\\u2022 `offset` (optional): Starting index (default 0)\\n\\n**Prerequisites:** User ID can be obtained from e.g. get_playlist (owner field), get_current_user_profile, or search_for_item.\\n\\n**Usage Examples:**\\n- View another user's playlists: `user_id=\\\"SLvTb0e3Rp3oLJ8YXl0dC5\\\", limit=20`\\n- Browse creator's playlists on their profile page\\n\\n**Returns:** Object with items array (public playlist objects owned by the user), total count, limit, and offset.\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n<details class=\\\"tool\\\">\\n<summary>get_playlist_cover_image</summary>\\n\\nRetrieves the cover image(s) for a specific playlist in multiple resolutions.\\n\\n**Parameters:**\\n\\u2022 `playlist_id` (required): The Spotify playlist ID\\n\\n**Prerequisites:** Playlist ID can be obtained from e.g. search_for_item, get_current_users_playlists, get_user_playlists, or get_category_playlists.\\n\\n**Usage Examples:**\\n- Get playlist cover art: `playlist_id=\\\"QDyH69WryQ7dPRXVOFmy2V\\\"`\\n\\n**Returns:** Array of image objects, each with url, height, and width. May be empty if no cover image is set.\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n<details class=\\\"tool\\\">\\n<summary>check_user_follows_playlist</summary>\\n\\nChecks if one or more users are following a specific playlist.\\n\\n**Parameters:**\\n\\u2022 `playlist_id` (required): The Spotify playlist ID\\n\\u2022 `user_ids` (required): Array of user IDs to check (maximum 5)\\n\\n**Prerequisites:** Playlist ID can be obtained from e.g. search_for_item or get_current_users_playlists. User IDs can be obtained from get_current_user_profile or get_playlist (owner field).\\n\\n**Usage Examples:**\\n- Check if current user follows: `playlist_id=\\\"...\\\", user_ids=[\\\"smuqPNFPXrJKcEt943KrY8\\\"]`\\n- Check multiple users: `playlist_id=\\\"...\\\", user_ids=[\\\"smuqPNFPXrJKcEt943KrY8\\\", \\\"SLvTb0e3Rp3oLJ8YXl0dC5\\\"]`\\n\\n**Returns:** Array of booleans in same order as input user IDs, where true means following and false means not following.\\n\\n**Behavior Notes:** Very efficient for batch checking.\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n<details class=\\\"tool\\\">\\n<summary>check_user_follows_artists_or_users</summary>\\n\\nChecks if the current user follows one or more artists or users.\\n\\n**Parameters:**\\n\\u2022 `ids` (required): Array of Spotify IDs to check (maximum 50)\\n\\u2022 `type` (required): Either \\\"artist\\\" or \\\"user\\\" to specify what type of IDs are provided\\n\\n**Prerequisites:** Artist IDs can be obtained from e.g. search_for_item, get_album, or get_artists_related_artists. User IDs can be obtained from get_current_user_profile or get_playlist (owner field).\\n\\n**Usage Examples:**\\n- Check artist follows: `ids=[\\\"W0e71GNltAWtwmOaMZcm1J\\\", \\\"DqJ4SeZM7iQuxSkKOdQvTB\\\"], type=\\\"artist\\\"`\\n- Check user follows: `ids=[\\\"SLvTb0e3Rp3oLJ8YXl0dC5\\\"], type=\\\"user\\\"`\\n\\n**Returns:** Array of booleans in same order as input IDs, indicating follow status for each.\\n\\n**Behavior Notes:** Efficient for batch checking follow status on browse pages.\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n<details class=\\\"tool\\\">\\n<summary>get_followed_artists</summary>\\n\\nRetrieves all artists that the current user follows with pagination support.\\n\\n**Parameters:**\\n\\u2022 `limit` (optional): Maximum artists (1-50, default 20)\\n\\u2022 `after` (optional): Last artist ID from previous request for cursor-based pagination\\n\\n**Usage Examples:**\\n- Get followed artists: `limit=20`\\n- Cursor pagination: `limit=20, after=\\\"W0e71GNltAWtwmOaMZcm1J\\\"`\\n- Show user's followed artists library\\n\\n**Returns:** Object with artists object containing items array (full artist objects), total count, and cursor information.\\n\\n**Behavior Notes:** Uses cursor-based pagination with \\\"after\\\" parameter instead of offset. The after value should be the last artist ID from the previous response. \\n\\n</details>\\n\\n<details class=\\\"tool\\\">\\n<summary>get_categories</summary>\\n\\nRetrieves all browse categories available on Spotify for content discovery.\\n\\n**Parameters:**\\n\\u2022 `country` (optional): ISO 3166-1 alpha-2 country code for localized categories (not used - can be set but will not be applied)\\n\\u2022 `locale` (optional): Language code (e.g., \\\"en_US\\\", \\\"es_MX\\\") for category names (not used - can be set but will not be applied)\\n\\u2022 `limit` (optional): Maximum categories (1-50, default 20)\\n\\u2022 `offset` (optional): Starting index (default 0)\\n\\n**Usage Examples:**\\n- Get all categories: `limit=50`\\n- Localized categories: `country=\\\"US\\\", locale=\\\"en_US\\\"`\\n- Paginate: `limit=20, offset=20`\\n\\n**Returns:** Object with categories object containing items array (category objects with id, name, icons), total count, limit, and offset.\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n<details class=\\\"tool\\\">\\n<summary>get_category</summary>\\n\\nRetrieves detailed information about a specific browse category.\\n\\n**Parameters:**\\n\\u2022 `category_id` (required): The Spotify category ID (e.g., \\\"0ZUBhfQhoczohmoxWGZpxj\\\")\\n\\u2022 `country` (optional): ISO 3166-1 alpha-2 country code\\n\\u2022 `locale` (optional): Language code for localized name\\n\\n**Prerequisites:** Category ID must exist in the database. Can be obtained from get_categories.\\n\\n**Usage Examples:**\\n- Get category details: `category_id=\\\"0ZUBhfQhoczohmoxWGZpxj\\\"`\\n- Localized category: `category_id=\\\"...\\\", locale=\\\"es_MX\\\"`\\n\\n**Returns:** Category object with id, name, icons array, and href.\\n\\n**Behavior Notes:** Returns category metadata only (id, name, icons, href), not any items within that category.\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n<details class=\\\"tool\\\">\\n<summary>get_category_playlists</summary>\\n\\nRetrieves playlists. Returns playlists with this category.\\n\\n**BUG - will return ALL playlists, not just those for the set category**\\n\\n**Parameters:**\\n\\u2022 `category_id` (required): The Spotify category ID\\n\\u2022 `country` (optional): ISO 3166-1 alpha-2 country code (not used - can be set but will not be applied)\\n\\u2022 `limit` (optional): Maximum playlists (1-50, default 20)\\n\\u2022 `offset` (optional): Starting index (default 0)\\n\\n**Prerequisites:** Category ID must exist. Can be obtained from get_categories.\\n\\n**Usage Examples:**\\n- Get Workout category playlists: `category_id=\\\"Mora0MAirzOLgW875YAWag\\\", limit=20`\\n- Country-specific playlists: `category_id=\\\"...\\\", country=\\\"US\\\"`\\n\\n**Returns:** Object with playlists object containing items array of all playlist objects, total count, limit, and offset.\\n\\n**Behavior Notes:**\\n\\u26a0\\ufe0f **Simulation limitation:**\\n- The tool does not effectively filter playlists by category - it returns all playlists from the playlists collection regardless of which category was specified.\\n- The country parameter is validated but not used for filtering results.\\n- You can still use this tool and its output for testing the agent's calls for category-based playlist browsing, but be aware that the returned playlists will not actually be specific to the requested category and will need further filtering.\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n<details class=\\\"tool\\\">\\n<summary>get_featured_playlists</summary>\\n\\nRetrieves all playlists from Spotify DB as \\\"featured\\\".\\n\\n**Parameters:**\\n\\u2022 `country` (optional): ISO 3166-1 alpha-2 country code (not used)\\n\\u2022 `locale` (optional): Language code for localized content (not used)\\n\\u2022 `timestamp` (optional): ISO 8601 timestamp for time-specific recommendations (e.g., \\\"2023-01-01T12:00:00\\\") (not used)\\n\\u2022 `limit` (optional): Maximum playlists (1-50, default 20)\\n\\u2022 `offset` (optional): Starting index (default 0)\\n\\n**Usage Examples:**\\n- Get current featured playlists: `country=\\\"US\\\", limit=10`\\n- Time-specific features: `timestamp=\\\"2023-12-31T23:00:00\\\", country=\\\"US\\\"`\\n- Browse tab featured section: `limit=20`\\n\\n**Returns:** Object with optional message string and playlists object containing items array, total count, limit, and offset.\\n\\n**Behavior Notes:**\\n\\u26a0\\ufe0f **Limitation:**\\n- Returns all playlists from the playlists collection as \\\"featured\\\" regardless of actual featured status.\\n- The country, locale, and timestamp parameters can be set but are not used by the tool to filter the results.\\n- You can still use this tool to test the agent's calls in your tasks, but be aware that all playlists are treated as featured.\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n<details class=\\\"tool\\\">\\n<summary>get_new_releases</summary>\\n\\nRetrieves newest-released albums on Spotify, useful for discovering fresh music.\\n\\n**Parameters:**\\n\\u2022 `country` (optional): ISO 3166-1 alpha-2 country code to filter by regional availability\\n\\u2022 `limit` (optional): Maximum albums (1-50, default 20)\\n\\u2022 `offset` (optional): Starting index (default 0)\\n\\n**Usage Examples:**\\n- Get new releases: `limit=20`\\n- Country-specific releases: `country=\\\"US\\\", limit=10`\\n- Paginate through releases: `offset=20, limit=20`\\n\\n**Returns:** Object with albums object containing items array (simplified album objects), total count, limit, and offset.\\n\\n**Behavior Notes:** Returns all albums from the database sorted by release_date (newest first).\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n<details class=\\\"tool\\\">\\n<summary>get_available_genre_seeds</summary>\\n\\nRetrieves the complete list of genre seeds available for generating recommendations. **Seeds** are input parameters for get_recommendations that specify what type of music to find (artist, track, or genre-based).\\n\\n**Parameters:** None\\n\\n**Usage Examples:**\\n- Build genre filter for music discovery\\n- Validate genre seeds before calling get_recommendations\\n\\n**Returns:** Object with genres array containing available genre seed strings (e.g., [\\\"acoustic\\\", \\\"afrobeat\\\", \\\"alt-rock\\\", \\\"alternative\\\", \\\"ambient\\\", ...]).\\n\\n**Behavior Notes:** Returns the genre list stored in the database (10 genres in default DB). These exact genre strings must be used when calling get_recommendations with seed_genres parameter.\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n<details class=\\\"tool\\\">\\n<summary>get_recommendations</summary>\\n\\nGenerates track recommendations based on seed artists, tracks, and/or genres. Seeds are meant to influence recommendations (e.g., \\\"find tracks similar to this artist/genre/track\\\").\\n\\n**bug - tool will not apply seeds**\\n\\n**Parameters:**\\n\\u2022 `seed_artists` (optional): Array of artist IDs (up to 5 total seeds combined)\\n\\u2022 `seed_genres` (optional): Array of genre strings from get_available_genre_seeds (up to 5 total seeds combined)\\n\\u2022 `seed_tracks` (optional): Array of track IDs (up to 5 total seeds combined)\\n\\u2022 `limit` (optional): Number of recommendations (1-100, default 20)\\n\\u2022 `market` (optional): ISO 3166-1 alpha-2 country code\\n\\n**Prerequisites:** At least one seed (artist, genre, or track) must be provided. Total seeds cannot exceed 5. Genre seeds must be from get_available_genre_seeds list.\\n\\n**Usage Examples:**\\n- Artist-based radio: `seed_artists=[\\\"W0e71GNltAWtwmOaMZcm1J\\\"], limit=20`\\n- Genre discovery: `seed_genres=[\\\"rock\\\", \\\"jazz\\\"], limit=30`\\n- Mixed seeds: `seed_artists=[\\\"W0e71GNltAWtwmOaMZcm1J\\\"], seed_tracks=[\\\"WSB9PMCMqpdEBFpMrMfS3h\\\"], seed_genres=[\\\"pop\\\"]`\\n\\n**Returns:** Object with tracks array (full track objects) and seeds array (echoes back the provided seeds with metadata).\\n\\n**Behavior Notes:**\\n\\u26a0\\ufe0f **Simulation limitation:**\\n- The tool does not effectively filter by seed input - it will accept the seed parameters, but only returns tracks from the database filtered by market parameter.\\n- You can still use this tool, instructing the agent to use certain seed parameters to get recommendations and using its output if the call itself was correct, but be aware that the actual list will not reflect the seed input values.\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n<details class=\\\"tool\\\">\\n<summary>search_for_item</summary>\\n\\nSearches Spotify's catalog for content matching a query string across multiple types including music, podcasts, and audiobooks.\\n\\n**Parameters:**\\n\\u2022 `q` (required): Search query string. \\u26a0\\ufe0f Uses simple case-insensitive substring matching on the names of the item type set by the `type` parameter only (i.e. a search for albums will only check the names of albums, not any tracks or artists). Does not support boolean operators (AND, OR, NOT) or advanced search syntax (field filters like artist:, album:, wildcards, etc.)\\n\\u2022 `type` (required): Comma-separated types to search - \\\"album\\\", \\\"artist\\\", \\\"playlist\\\", \\\"track\\\", \\\"show\\\" (podcast series), \\\"episode\\\" (podcast episode), \\\"audiobook\\\"\\n\\u2022 `market` (optional): ISO 3166-1 alpha-2 country code\\n\\u2022 `limit` (optional): Maximum items per type (1-50, default 20)\\n\\u2022 `offset` (optional): Starting index (default 0)\\n\\u2022 `include_external` (optional): \\\"audio\\\" to include externally hosted content\\n\\n**Usage Examples:**\\n- Search tracks: `q=\\\"Test\\\", type=\\\"track\\\"`\\n- Multi-type search: `q=\\\"Popular\\\", type=\\\"artist,album,playlist\\\"`\\n- Search podcasts: `q=\\\"Tech Talk\\\", type=\\\"show,episode\\\"`\\n- Search audiobooks: `q=\\\"Harry Potter\\\", type=\\\"audiobook\\\"`\\n- No results case: `q=\\\"nonexistent_xyz\\\", type=\\\"track\\\"` returns empty results\\n\\n**Returns:** Object with keys for each searched type (e.g., tracks, artists, albums, shows, episodes, audiobooks), each containing object with items array, total count, limit, and offset.\\n\\n**Behavior Notes:** Can search multiple types in one call. Each type gets its own pagination. Returns empty arrays (total: 0) for no matches, doesn't error.\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n<details class=\\\"write-tools\\\">\\n<summary>\\u270f\\ufe0f State-Changing Tools</summary>\\n\\n<details class=\\\"tool\\\">\\n<summary>save_albums_for_user</summary>\\n\\nSaves one or more albums to the current user's personal library for easy access.\\n\\n**Parameters:**\\n\\u2022 `album_ids` (required): Array of album IDs to save (maximum 50)\\n\\n**Prerequisites:** Album IDs can be obtained from e.g. search_for_item, get_artists_albums, get_album, or get_new_releases.\\n\\n**Usage Examples:**\\n- Save single album: `album_ids=[\\\"4kBp5iVByDSAUc0lb78jCZ\\\"]`\\n- Batch save albums user discovers: `album_ids=[\\\"4kBp5iVByDSAUc0lb78jCZ\\\", \\\"gJIfNlJdPASNffy7UY2V6D\\\", \\\"5V17F52VsJ3ZDIF1iYxe6D\\\"]`\\n\\n**State Changes:** Adds albums to the current user's saved_albums collection with current timestamp as added_at. If album is already saved, no duplicate is created (idempotent operation).\\n\\n**Returns:** Object with message: \\\"The album is saved\\\".\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n<details class=\\\"tool\\\">\\n<summary>remove_albums_for_user</summary>\\n\\nRemoves one or more albums from the current user's personal library.\\n\\n**Parameters:**\\n\\u2022 `album_ids` (required): Array of album IDs to remove (maximum 50)\\n\\n**Prerequisites:** Album IDs from get_users_saved_albums.\\n\\n**Usage Examples:**\\n- Remove single album: `album_ids=[\\\"5V17F52VsJ3ZDIF1iYxe6D\\\"]`\\n- Batch remove: `album_ids=[\\\"4kBp5iVByDSAUc0lb78jCZ\\\", \\\"gJIfNlJdPASNffy7UY2V6D\\\", \\\"5V17F52VsJ3ZDIF1iYxe6D\\\"]`\\n\\n**State Changes:** Removes specified albums from the current user's saved_albums collection entry. Removes the entire saved album object including the added_at timestamp.\\n\\n**Returns:** Object with message: \\\"Album(s) have been removed from the library\\\".\\n\\n**Behavior Notes:** Idempotent operation - removing an album that isn't saved doesn't cause an error. The album remains in the global catalog, only the user's save relationship is removed.\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n<details class=\\\"tool\\\">\\n<summary>follow_artists_or_users</summary>\\n\\nAdds the current user as a follower of one or more artists or users.\\n\\n**Parameters:**\\n\\u2022 `ids` (required): Array of Spotify IDs to follow (maximum 50)\\n\\u2022 `type` (required): Either \\\"artist\\\" or \\\"user\\\" to specify what type to follow\\n\\n**Prerequisites:** Artist IDs can be obtained from e.g. search_for_item, get_album, get_artists_related_artists, or get_followed_artists. User IDs can be obtained from get_current_user_profile or get_playlist (owner field).\\n\\n**Usage Examples:**\\n- Follow artists: `ids=[\\\"W0e71GNltAWtwmOaMZcm1J\\\", \\\"DqJ4SeZM7iQuxSkKOdQvTB\\\"], type=\\\"artist\\\"`\\n- Follow single user: `ids=[\\\"SLvTb0e3Rp3oLJ8YXl0dC5\\\"], type=\\\"user\\\"`\\n\\n**State Changes:** Adds the specified IDs to the current user's followed_artists or followed_users collection depending on type. Following an artist adds you to their follower count.\\n\\n**Returns:** Success confirmation.\\n\\n**Behavior Notes:** Entire call will fail if any one ID is invalid\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n<details class=\\\"tool\\\">\\n<summary>unfollow_artists_or_users</summary>\\n\\nRemoves the current user as a follower of one or more artists or users.\\n\\n**Parameters:**\\n\\u2022 `ids` (required): Array of Spotify IDs to unfollow (maximum 50)\\n\\u2022 `type` (required): Either \\\"artist\\\" or \\\"user\\\"\\n\\n**Prerequisites:** Artist IDs can be obtained from e.g. search_for_item, get_album, get_artists_related_artists, or get_followed_artists. User IDs can be obtained from get_current_user_profile or get_playlist (owner field).\\n\\n**Usage Examples:**\\n- Unfollow artists: `ids=[\\\"W0e71GNltAWtwmOaMZcm1J\\\"], type=\\\"artist\\\"`\\n- Unfollow multiple users: `ids=[\\\"smuqPNFPXrJKcEt943KrY8\\\", \\\"SLvTb0e3Rp3oLJ8YXl0dC5\\\"], type=\\\"user\\\"`\\n\\n**State Changes:** Removes the specified IDs from the current user's followed_artists or followed_users collection. Decrements the follower count for artists.\\n\\n**Returns:** Success confirmation.\\n\\n**Behavior Notes:** Idempotent - unfollowing entities you don't follow doesn't cause errors.\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n<details class=\\\"tool\\\">\\n<summary>follow_playlist</summary>\\n\\nAdds the current user as a follower of a playlist, adding it to their library.\\n\\n**Parameters:**\\n\\u2022 `playlist_id` (required): The Spotify playlist ID to follow\\n\\u2022 `public` (optional): Whether to follow publicly (default true). If false, follow is private\\n\\n**Prerequisites:** Playlist ID can be obtained from e.g. search_for_item, get_user_playlists, get_category_playlists, or get_featured_playlists.\\n\\n**Usage Examples:**\\n- Follow publicly: `playlist_id=\\\"UgsCJJwpTgHzXvFg3QW3yQ\\\", public=true`\\n- Follow privately: `playlist_id=\\\"UgsCJJwpTgHzXvFg3QW3yQ\\\", public=false`\\n- Add playlist to library: Follow to add to user's playlist collection\\n\\n**State Changes:** Adds playlist to current user's followed_playlists collection with the public flag. Publicly followed playlists appear in the user's public profile, private follows do not.\\n\\n**Returns:** Success confirmation.\\n\\n**Behavior Notes:** Unlike artists/users, playlists have a public/private follow distinction. The public parameter can be changed later by following again with a different value.\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n<details class=\\\"tool\\\">\\n<summary>unfollow_playlist</summary>\\n\\nRemoves the current user as a follower of a playlist, removing it from their library.\\n\\n**Parameters:**\\n\\u2022 `playlist_id` (required): The Spotify playlist ID to unfollow\\n\\n**Prerequisites:** Playlist ID can be obtained from e.g. search_for_item, get_user_playlists, get_category_playlists, or get_featured_playlists; no error if not following.\\n\\n**Usage Examples:**\\n- Unfollow playlist: `playlist_id=\\\"UgsCJJwpTgHzXvFg3QW3yQ\\\"`\\n- Remove from library: Clean up followed playlists\\n\\n**State Changes:** Removes playlist from current user's followed_playlists collection entry. Both public and private follows are removed.\\n\\n**Returns:** Success confirmation.\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n<details class=\\\"tool\\\">\\n<summary>create_playlist</summary>\\n\\nCreates a new empty playlist owned by the specified user. New playlists start empty (0 tracks) and can be added to in a subsequent call to `add_items_to_playlist`.\\n\\n**Parameters:**\\n\\u2022 `user_id` (required): The Spotify user ID who will own the playlist\\n\\u2022 `name` (required): Playlist name (e.g., \\\"My Workout Mix\\\")\\n\\u2022 `public` (optional): Whether playlist is public (default true). Collaborative playlists must be private (public=false).\\n\\u2022 `collaborative` (optional): Whether others can modify (default false)\\n\\u2022 `description` (optional): Playlist description text\\n\\n**Prerequisites:** User ID can be obtained from e.g. get_current_user_profile.\\n\\n**Usage Examples:**\\n- Basic playlist: `user_id=\\\"smuqPNFPXrJKcEt943KrY8\\\", name=\\\"My Playlist\\\"`\\n- Private playlist: `user_id=\\\"smuqPNFPXrJKcEt943KrY8\\\", name=\\\"Secret Mix\\\", public=false`\\n- Collaborative: `user_id=\\\"...\\\", name=\\\"Party Playlist\\\", collaborative=true`\\n- With description: `name=\\\"Workout Mix\\\", description=\\\"High energy tracks\\\"`\\n\\n**State Changes:** Creates new playlist in playlists collection with auto-generated ID. Adds to user's user_playlists collection. Initializes with 0 tracks and generates initial snapshot_id. Creates entry in playlist_tracks collection with empty items array.\\n\\n**Returns:** Complete playlist object.\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n<details class=\\\"tool\\\">\\n<summary>add_items_to_playlist</summary>\\n\\nAdds one or more tracks or podcast episodes to a playlist at a specific position in the playlist or at the end.\\n\\nTrack/episode IDs must be alphanumeric-only to work with this tool.\\n\\n**Parameters:**\\n\\u2022 `playlist_id` (required): The Spotify playlist ID\\n\\u2022 `uris` (required): Array of Spotify URIs to add (maximum 100). Supports \\\"spotify:track:ID\\\" for music tracks and \\\"spotify:episode:ID\\\" for podcast episodes\\n\\u2022 `position` (optional): 0-indexed position in the playlist to insert at (i.e. the first item in the playlist is at position 0; the second at position 1; etc.). If omitted, it adds the new items to the end\\n\\n**Prerequisites:** Playlist ID can be obtained from e.g. create_playlist or get_current_users_playlists. Track IDs can be obtained from search_for_item, get_album_tracks, get_artists_top_tracks, or get_recommendations (format as spotify:track:ID URIs). Episode IDs can be obtained from search_for_item with `type=\\\"episode\\\"` (format as spotify:episode:ID URIs).\\n\\n**Usage Examples:**\\n- Append tracks: `playlist_id=\\\"...\\\", uris=[\\\"spotify:track:track1\\\", \\\"spotify:track:track2\\\"]`\\n- Add podcast episode: `playlist_id=\\\"...\\\", uris=[\\\"spotify:episode:episode1\\\"]`\\n- Mix tracks and episodes: `playlist_id=\\\"...\\\", uris=[\\\"spotify:track:track1\\\", \\\"spotify:episode:episode1\\\", \\\"spotify:track:track2\\\"]`\\n- Insert at start: `playlist_id=\\\"...\\\", uris=[\\\"spotify:track:track1\\\"], position=0`\\n- Insert at position: `playlist_id=\\\"...\\\", uris=[\\\"spotify:episode:episode1\\\"], position=5`\\n\\n**State Changes:** Adds the specified tracks and/or episodes to the playlist's playlist_tracks items array, or inserts them at the requested position. Generates new snapshot_id. Each item includes added_at timestamp and added_by user reference.\\n\\n**Returns:** New snapshot_id only.\\n\\n**Behavior Notes:** Duplicate tracks and episodes can be added.\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n<details class=\\\"tool\\\">\\n<summary>remove_playlist_items</summary>\\n\\nRemoves one or more tracks or episodes from a playlist by URI, removing ALL occurrences if duplicates exist.\\n\\nTrack/episode IDs must be alphanumeric-only to work with this tool.\\n\\n**Parameters:**\\n\\u2022 `playlist_id` (required): The Spotify playlist ID\\n\\u2022 `tracks` (required): Array of objects, each with `uri` field (e.g., [{\\\"uri\\\": \\\"spotify:track:...\\\"}] or [{\\\"uri\\\": \\\"spotify:episode:...\\\"}]) (maximum 100)\\n\\u2022 `snapshot_id` (optional): Playlist snapshot ID - include to confirm that other users have not modified the playlist since the agent last accessed it (for collaborative playlists)\\n\\n**Prerequisites:** Playlist ID can be obtained from e.g. get_current_users_playlists. Track and episode URIs can be obtained from get_playlist_items (format as spotify:track:ID or spotify:episode:ID).\\n\\n**Usage Examples:**\\n- Remove tracks: `playlist_id=\\\"...\\\", tracks=[{\\\"uri\\\": \\\"spotify:track:track1\\\"}, {\\\"uri\\\": \\\"spotify:track:track2\\\"}]`\\n- Remove episode: `playlist_id=\\\"...\\\", tracks=[{\\\"uri\\\": \\\"spotify:episode:episode1\\\"}]`\\n- Mix removal: `playlist_id=\\\"...\\\", tracks=[{\\\"uri\\\": \\\"spotify:track:track1\\\"}, {\\\"uri\\\": \\\"spotify:episode:episode1\\\"}]`\\n- With snapshot check: `playlist_id=\\\"...\\\", tracks=[{\\\"uri\\\": \\\"...\\\"}], snapshot_id=\\\"snapshot_abc\\\"`\\n\\n**State Changes:** Removes ALL occurrences of the specified track and episode URIs from the playlist's items array. Generates new snapshot_id. Decrements total item count.\\n\\n**Returns:** Object with new snapshot_id only. Changes can be confirmed by calling get_playlist.\\n\\n**Behavior Notes:**\\n* Idempotent - removing non-existent items doesn't error.\\n* The call will fail if the current snapshot_id of the playlist does not match the one provided in the snapshot_id parameter, indicating that another user has modified the playlist already. In this case, the agent will need to call get_playlist to get an updated snapshot_id, then retry the call to this function with that new id.\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n<details class=\\\"tool\\\">\\n<summary>update_playlist_items</summary>\\n\\nThis tool can perform one of two actions within a single call:\\n* replace ALL tracks in a playlist with a new list (when including uris)\\n\\nOR\\n* reorder existing tracks (when using range/insert)\\n\\n**Parameters:**\\n\\u2022 `playlist_id` (required): The Spotify playlist ID\\n\\u2022 `uris` (optional): Array of Spotify URIs to REPLACE all tracks (maximum 100)\\n\\u2022 `range_start` (optional): Starting position of range to reorder\\n\\u2022 `insert_before` (optional): Position to insert reordered range before\\n\\u2022 `range_length` (optional): Length of range to reorder (default 1)\\n\\u2022 `snapshot_id` (optional): Playlist snapshot ID - include to confirm that other users have not modified the playlist since the agent last accessed it (for collaborative playlists)\\n\\n**Prerequisites:** Playlist ID can be obtained from e.g. create_playlist or get_current_users_playlists. Track URIs for replacement can be obtained from search_for_item or other track-returning tools.\\n\\n**Usage Examples:**\\n- Replace all tracks: `playlist_id=\\\"...\\\", uris=[\\\"spotify:track:track1\\\", \\\"spotify:track:track2\\\"]`\\n- Reorder: `playlist_id=\\\"...\\\", range_start=3, insert_before=0, range_length=2` (moves tracks 3-4 to start)\\n\\n**State Changes:**\\n* If uris provided: COMPLETELY REPLACES all tracks with new list, generates new snapshot_id.\\n* If only reorder params provided: Reorders tracks within the existing list, generates new snapshot_id.\\n\\n**Returns:** Object with new snapshot_id string.\\n\\n**Behavior Notes:** \\n* `uris` takes precendence - if both uris and reordering parameters are included, the tool will ignore the reordering parameters and just perform the replace action.\\n* DESTRUCTIVE when using uris - replaces entire playlist content. Use add_items_to_playlist to append instead.\\n* The call will fail if the current snapshot_id of the playlist does not match the one provided in the snapshot_id parameter, indicating that another user has modified the playlist already. In this case, the agent will need to call get_playlist to get an updated snapshot_id, then retry the call to this function with that new id.\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n<details class=\\\"tool\\\">\\n<summary>change_playlist_details</summary>\\n\\nModifies a playlist's name, description, and public/collaborative settings.\\n\\n**Parameters:**\\n\\u2022 `playlist_id` (required): The Spotify playlist ID\\n\\u2022 `name` (optional): New playlist name\\n\\u2022 `public` (optional): Change public/private status\\n\\u2022 `collaborative` (optional): Change collaborative status. Collaborative playlists must be private (public=false).\\n\\u2022 `description` (optional): Update description text\\n\\n**Prerequisites:** Playlist ID can be obtained from e.g. create_playlist or get_current_users_playlists.\\n\\n**Usage Examples:**\\n- Rename playlist: `playlist_id=\\\"...\\\", name=\\\"Updated Name\\\"`\\n- Make private: `playlist_id=\\\"...\\\", public=false`\\n- Update all metadata: `playlist_id=\\\"...\\\", name=\\\"New Name\\\", description=\\\"New desc\\\", public=false`\\n- Make collaborative: `playlist_id=\\\"...\\\", collaborative=true` (must also set public=false)\\n\\n**State Changes:** Updates the specified fields in the playlist object. Generates new snapshot_id. Other fields remain unchanged if not specified.\\n\\n**Returns:** Empty object {} (no success message). Changes can be confirmed by calling get_playlist.\\n\\n**Behavior Notes:** Only specified fields are updated, others remain unchanged.  \\n\\n</details>\\n\\n<details class=\\\"tool\\\">\\n<summary>add_custom_playlist_cover_image</summary>\\n\\nUploads a custom JPEG image to use as the cover for a playlist, replacing any existing image.\\n\\n**Parameters:**\\n\\u2022 `playlist_id` (required): The Spotify playlist ID\\n\\u2022 `image_data` (required): Base64-encoded JPEG image data (maximum 256 KB after decoding)\\n\\n**Prerequisites:** Playlist ID can be obtained from e.g. create_playlist or get_current_users_playlists. Image must be JPEG format and under 256 KB when decoded.\\n\\n**Usage Examples:**\\n- Set custom cover: `playlist_id=\\\"...\\\", image_data=\\\"<base64-encoded-jpeg>\\\"`\\n- Replace existing cover: Same call replaces previous image\\n\\n**State Changes:** Updates playlist_cover_images collection with new image data. Replaces any previous custom cover. Does not change snapshot_id (cover image changes don't affect playlist version).\\n\\n**Returns:** None (no response body). Confirm changes by calling get_playlist_cover_image.\\n\\n</details>\\n\\n</details>\\n\"\n                }\n                ];\n            const diffPatcher = jsondiffpatch.create({ objectHash: (obj, idx) => obj.id || obj.resourceName || `__index:${idx}` });\n            let currentScript = null, currentIndex = -1, currentMode = 'preview', docsOpen = false;\n            let currentJsonData = null, currentJsonDataPrev = null;\n            let smartFilterEnabled = true, isResizingDocs = false, showDiffView = false;\n\n            function toggleMenu() { mainMenu.classList.toggle('collapsed'); }\n            docsResizer.addEventListener('mousedown', (e) => { isResizingDocs = true; docsResizer.classList.add('resizing'); document.body.style.cursor = 'col-resize'; document.body.style.userSelect = 'none'; });\n            document.addEventListener('mousemove', (e) => {\n                if (!isResizingDocs) return;\n                const newWidth = document.body.clientWidth - e.clientX;\n                if (newWidth > 200 && newWidth < document.body.clientWidth - 100) document.body.style.setProperty('--docs-width', newWidth + 'px');\n            });\n            document.addEventListener('mouseup', () => { if (isResizingDocs) { isResizingDocs = false; docsResizer.classList.remove('resizing'); document.body.style.cursor = ''; document.body.style.userSelect = ''; } });\n            function showPreview(index) { switchMainView(index, 'preview'); }\n            function showJson(index) { switchMainView(index, 'json'); }\n\n            function switchMainView(index, mode) {\n                try {\n                    currentIndex = index; currentMode = mode; updateActiveRowState();\n                    const data = pageContents[index];\n\n                    currentJsonData = data.propsJson ? (data.propsJson.database || null) : null;\n                    currentJsonDataPrev = data.propsJsonPrev ? (data.propsJsonPrev.database || null) : null;\n\n                    docsContent.innerHTML = data.docsRaw ? marked.parse(data.docsRaw) : \"<div style='padding:32px;color:#666;font-style:italic;text-align:center;'>No documentation available.</div>\";\n                    if (mode === 'preview') renderPreview(index);\n                    else renderJson(index);\n                } catch (e) {\n                    console.error(\"Error switching view:\", e);\n                    contentArea.innerHTML = `<div style='padding:20px;color:#d93025;'><b>Error:</b> Could not switch view. <pre>${e.message}</pre></div>`;\n                }\n            }\n\n            function toggleDocs(index, event) {\n                if (event) event.stopPropagation();\n                if (index !== currentIndex) switchMainView(index, currentMode);\n                docsOpen = !docsOpen; if (docsOpen && index !== currentIndex) docsOpen = true;\n                updateDocsPanelState();\n            }\n\n            function renderPreview(index) {\n                if (currentScript) currentScript.remove();\n                const data = pageContents[index];\n\n                let finalUrl = data.bundleUrl;\n                if (typeof BASE_URL !== 'undefined') {\n                     finalUrl = data.bundleUrl.replace(\"BASE_URL\", BASE_URL);\n                }\n\n                window.__COMPONENT_CONFIG__ = {\n                    componentName: data.componentName,\n                    props: data.propsJson,\n                    bundleUrl: finalUrl\n                };\n\n                contentArea.innerHTML = `<div id=\"root\">Loading ${data.componentName}...</div>`;\n                currentScript = document.createElement('script');\n                currentScript.src = finalUrl;\n                currentScript.onerror = () => { contentArea.innerHTML = `<div style=\"padding:20px;color:#d93025;\"><b>Error:</b> Failed to load script.<br>${finalUrl}</div>`; };\n                document.body.appendChild(currentScript);\n            }\n\n            function renderJson(index) {\n                if (currentScript) currentScript.remove();\n                const canDiff = currentJsonDataPrev !== null;\n                const diffToggleHtml = canDiff ? `<label class=\"toggle-wrapper\" title=\"Show diff from previous state\"><div class=\"toggle-switch\"><input type=\"checkbox\" id=\"diffToggle\" ${showDiffView ? 'checked' : ''} onchange=\"toggleDiffView(this.checked)\"><span class=\"slider\"></span></div>Show Diff</label>` : '';\n                contentArea.innerHTML = `\n                    <div class=\"json-container\" id=\"json-container\">\n                        <div class=\"json-toolbar\">\n                            <div class=\"json-search-controls\" id=\"json-search-controls\">\n                                <input type=\"text\" id=\"jsonSearch\" class=\"json-search\" placeholder=\"Filter JSON...\" oninput=\"handleJsonFilter()\">\n                                <label class=\"toggle-wrapper\" title=\"Smart Filter\"><div class=\"toggle-switch\"><input type=\"checkbox\" id=\"smartFilterToggle\" ${smartFilterEnabled ? 'checked' : ''} onchange=\"toggleSmartFilter(this.checked)\"><span class=\"slider\"></span></div>Smart Filter</label>\n                            </div>\n                            ${diffToggleHtml}\n                        </div>\n                        <pre class=\"json-scroll-area\" id=\"jsonOutput\"></pre>\n                        <div class=\"json-diff-area\" id=\"jsonDiffOutput\"></div>\n                    </div>`;\n                toggleDiffView(showDiffView && canDiff);\n            }\n\n            function toggleDiffView(isDiff) {\n                showDiffView = isDiff;\n                const container = document.getElementById('json-container'); if (!container) return;\n                if (isDiff) {\n                    container.classList.add('diff-active');\n                    const diffOutput = document.getElementById('jsonDiffOutput');\n                    const delta = diffPatcher.diff(currentJsonDataPrev, currentJsonData);\n                    if (delta) { diffOutput.innerHTML = jsondiffpatch.formatters.html.format(delta, currentJsonDataPrev); }\n                    else { diffOutput.innerHTML = '<div style=\"padding:16px;color:#098658;font-style:italic;\">// No changes detected.</div>'; }\n                } else {\n                    container.classList.remove('diff-active');\n                    handleJsonFilter();\n                }\n            }\n            function updateActiveRowState() { menuRows.forEach((row, i) => { row.classList.remove('active', 'active-json', 'docs-open'); if (i === currentIndex) { row.classList.add(currentMode === 'preview' ? 'active' : 'active-json'); if (docsOpen) row.classList.add('docs-open'); } }); }\n            function updateDocsPanelState() { if (docsOpen) { docsPanel.classList.add('open'); docsResizer.style.display = 'block'; } else { docsPanel.classList.remove('open'); docsResizer.style.display = 'none'; } updateActiveRowState(); }\n            function toggleSmartFilter(checked) { smartFilterEnabled = checked; handleJsonFilter(); }\n            function handleJsonFilter() {\n                const term = document.getElementById('jsonSearch')?.value.toLowerCase(); const output = document.getElementById('jsonOutput'); if (!output) return;\n                if (!term) { output.innerHTML = syntaxHighlight(currentJsonData); return; }\n                const filtered = smartFilter(currentJsonData, term, smartFilterEnabled);\n                output.innerHTML = (filtered === undefined) ? '<span style=\"color:#7f848e; font-style:italic;\">// No matches found</span>' : syntaxHighlight(filtered);\n            }\n            function smartFilter(obj, term, useSmartMode) {\n                if (typeof obj !== 'object' || obj === null) return String(obj).toLowerCase().includes(term) ? obj : undefined;\n                if (Array.isArray(obj)) { const f = obj.map(i => smartFilter(i, term, useSmartMode)).filter(x => x !== undefined); return f.length > 0 ? f : undefined; }\n                let res = {}, has = false, child = false;\n                for (const [k, v] of Object.entries(obj)) { if (k.toLowerCase().includes(term)) { res[k] = v; has = true; continue; } const fv = smartFilter(v, term, useSmartMode); if (fv !== undefined) { has = true; child = true; res[k] = fv; } }\n                if (useSmartMode && child && (obj.id || obj.threadId || obj.emailAddress || obj.resourceName || obj.alarm_id || obj.timer_id)) return obj;\n                return has ? res : undefined;\n            }\n            function syntaxHighlight(json) {\n                if (json === null || json === undefined) return '<span class=\"j-null\">null</span>';\n                if (typeof json !== 'string') json = JSON.stringify(json, undefined, 2);\n                return json.replace(/&/g, '&amp;').replace(/</g, '&lt;').replace(/>/g, '&gt;').replace(/(\"(\\u[a-zA-Z0-9]{4}|\\[^u]|[^\\\"])*\"(\\s*:)?|\b(true|false|null)\b|-?\\d+(?:\\d*)?(?:[eE][+\\-]?\\d+)?)/g, m => {\n                    let c = 'j-number'; if (/^\"/.test(m)) c = /:$/.test(m) ? 'j-key' : 'j-string'; else if (/true|false/.test(m)) c = 'j-boolean'; else if (/null/.test(m)) c = 'j-null'; return '<span class=\"' + c + '\">' + m + '</span>'; });\n            }\n            if (pageContents.length > 0) showPreview(0);\n            else contentArea.innerHTML = \"<div style='display:flex;align-items:center;justify-content:center;height:100%;color:#666;'>No services loaded.</div>\";\n            if (window.innerWidth <= 768) mainMenu.classList.add('collapsed');\n        </script>\n    </body>\n    </html>", "env_request_fc_service_name": null, "env_request_fc_function_name": null, "env_request_fc_parameters": null, "test_agent_prompt": null, "test_conversation_history": null, "test_agent": {"raw_json": null, "original_response": null, "edited_response": null, "original_message": null}, "services_needed": ["clock", "confluence", "device_actions", "device_setting", "hubspot", "spotify"], "task_sim_world_state": null, "int_cmd": null, "server_url": null, "optional_comments": "Not my very first Honeydew submission, but my third overall and first in this latest iteration, which I found to need a lot of investigation and clarification to make it to the end of the task. Produced by Bill Drummond and Jimmy Cauty.</p>\\n<h3>Cultural Context</h3>\\n<p>A landmark track of the UK Acid House and Rave movement. famously deleted from their back catalog in 1992.</p>\\n<p><strong>Strategic Connection (The Orb):</strong> There is a direct lineage between this track and <em>Little Fluffy Clouds</em> via member Jimmy Cauty.</p>\\n<p><strong>Influenced Artists:</strong> The KLF's use of cinematic samples directly influenced the work of <strong>The Future Sound of London</strong>, specifically their breakout track <strong>\\\"Papua New Guinea\\\"</strong>.</p>\\n<h3>Marketing Potential</h3>\\n<p>Unmatched for \\\"Retro-Futurism\\\" branding.</p>\", \"representation\": \"storage\"}}, \"version\": {\"number\": 2, \"minorEdit\": false}, \"history\": {\"latest\": true, \"createdBy\": {\"type\": \"known\", \"username\": \"system\", \"displayName\": \"System User\"}, \"createdDate\": \"2025-12-22T15:00:00.000Z\"}, \"link\": \"/wiki/rest/api/content/9\"}, \"10\": {\"id\": \"10\", \"type\": \"page\", \"title\": \"NMR: The KLF - Justified and Ancient\", \"spaceKey\": \"NMR\", \"status\": \"current\", \"body\": {\"storage\": {\"value\": \"<h2>New Music Research Report</h2>\\n<p><strong>Song Title:</strong> Justified & Ancient (Stand by The JAMs)</p>\\n<p><strong>Artist:</strong> The KLF featuring Tammy Wynette</p>\\n<hr />\\n<h3>Background & History</h3>\\n<p>Released in 1991, this version of the track is a collaborative effort between the KLF and American country music legend Tammy Wynette. It reached #2 in the UK and #11 in the US. The song is famous for its surrealist lyrics about \\\"Mu Mu Land\\\" and its unlikely stylistic blend of dance-pop and country.</p>\\n<h3>Cultural Context</h3>\\n<p>A prime example of the KLF's \\\"pop as performance art\\\" approach. The collaboration with Wynette was seen as a bold cross-genre experiment that bridged the gap between the Nashville establishment and the British rave scene. It was Bush's most successful 1980s release.</p>\\n<h3>Cultural Context</h3>\\n<p>Experienced a massive global resurgence in 2022 after being featured prominently in Season 4 of the Netflix series <em>Stranger Things</em>. It reached #1 in the UK and #3 in the US decades after its debut, introducing Bush to Gen Z.</p>\\n<h3>Marketing Potential</h3>\\n<p>High potential for \\\"Nostalgia Core\\\" branding. Produced by Dan Nigro (Olivia Rodrigo). It marks a pivotal shift in Roan's career toward mainstream pop stardom.</p>\\n<h3>Cultural Context</h3>\\n<p>Became a \\\"sleeper hit\\\" and viral sensation on TikTok and Reels. Often cited as a defining queer pop anthem of the mid-2020s, fueled by Roan's theatrical live performances at Coachella and Governors Ball.</p>\\n<h3>Marketing Potential</h3>\\n<p>Ideal for \\\"Main Character Energy\\\" campaigns. 3am Eternal\", \"spaceKey\": \"NMR\", \"status\": \"current\", \"body\": {\"storage\": {\"value\": \"<h2>New Music Research Report</h2>\\n<p><strong>Song Title:</strong> 3am Eternal (Live at the S.S.L.)</p>\\n<p><strong>Artist:</strong> The KLF</p>\\n<hr />\\n<h3>Background & History</h3>\\n<p>Originally released in 1989 as part of their \\\"Pure Trance\\\" series, the definitive \\\"Stadium House\\\" version was released in 1991. Produced by Bill Drummond and Jimmy Cauty.</p>\\n<h3>Cultural Context</h3>\\n<p>A landmark track of the UK Acid House and Rave movement. famously deleted from their back catalog in 1992.</p>\\n<p><strong>Strategic Connection (The Orb):</strong> There is a direct lineage between this track and <em>Little Fluffy Clouds</em> via member Jimmy Cauty.</p>\\n<p><strong>Influenced Artists:</strong> The KLF's use of cinematic samples directly influenced the work of <strong>The Future Sound of London</strong>, specifically their breakout track <strong>\\\"Papua New Guinea\\\"</strong>.</p>\\n<h3>Marketing Potential</h3>\\n<p>Unmatched for \\\"Retro-Futurism\\\" branding.</p>\", \"representation\": \"storage\"}}, \"version\": {\"number\": 2, \"minorEdit\": false}, \"history\": {\"latest\": true, \"createdBy\": {\"type\": \"known\", \"username\": \"system\", \"displayName\": \"System User\"}, \"createdDate\": \"2025-12-22T15:00:00.000Z\"}, \"link\": \"/wiki/rest/api/content/9\"}, \"10\": {\"id\": \"10\", \"type\": \"page\", \"title\": \"NMR: The KLF - Justified and Ancient\", \"spaceKey\": \"NMR\", \"status\": \"current\", \"body\": {\"storage\": {\"value\": \"<h2>New Music Research Report</h2>\\n<p><strong>Song Title:</strong> Justified & Ancient (Stand by The JAMs)</p>\\n<p><strong>Artist:</strong> The KLF featuring Tammy Wynette</p>\\n<hr />\\n<h3>Background & History</h3>\\n<p>Released in 1991, this version of the track is a collaborative effort between the KLF and American country music legend Tammy Wynette. It reached #2 in the UK and #11 in the US. The song is famous for its surrealist lyrics about \\\"Mu Mu Land\\\" and its unlikely stylistic blend of dance-pop and country.</p>\\n<h3>Cultural Context</h3>\\n<p>A prime example of the KLF's \\\"pop as performance art\\\" approach. The collaboration with Wynette was seen as a bold cross-genre experiment that bridged the gap between the Nashville establishment and the British rave scene. It remains one of the most recognizable tracks of the early 90s.</p>\\n<h3>Marketing Potential</h3>\\n<p>Excellent for \\\"Unexpected Collaboration\\\" or \\\"Genre-Bending\\\" themed campaigns. The track has a high nostalgic recognition factor and a kitschy, uplifting energy suitable for lifestyle and fashion branding.</p>\", \"representation\": \"storage\"}}, \"version\": {\"number\": 1, \"minorEdit\": false}, \"history\": {\"latest\": true, \"createdBy\": {\"type\": \"known\", \"username\": \"system\", \"displayName\": \"System User\"}, \"createdDate\": \"2025-12-22T16:00:00.000Z\"}, \"_links\": {\"self\": \"/wiki/rest/api/content/10\"}}}, \"long_task_counter\": 1, \"content_labels\": {}, \"long_tasks\": {}, \"spaces\": {\"NMR\": {\"name\": \"New Music Research\", \"description\": \"Central knowledge base for the New Music Research division. It was Bush's most successful 1980s release.</p>\\n<h3>Cultural Context</h3>\\n<p>Experienced a massive global resurgence in 2022 after being featured prominently in Season 4 of the Netflix series <em>Stranger Things</em>. 3am Eternal\", \"spaceKey\": \"NMR\", \"status\": \"current\", \"body\": {\"storage\": {\"value\": \"<h2>New Music Research Report</h2>\\n<p><strong>Song Title:</strong> 3am Eternal (Live at the S.S.L.)</p>\\n<p><strong>Artist:</strong> The KLF</p>\\n<hr />\\n<h3>Background & History</h3>\\n<p>Originally released in 1989 as part of their \\\"Pure Trance\\\" series, the definitive \\\"Stadium House\\\" version was released in 1991. Produced by Bill Drummond and Jimmy Cauty.</p>\\n<h3>Cultural Context</h3>\\n<p>A landmark track of the UK Acid House and Rave movement. famously deleted from their back catalog in 1992.</p>\\n<p><strong>Strategic Connection (The Orb):</strong> There is a direct lineage between this track and <em>Little Fluffy Clouds</em> via member Jimmy Cauty.</p>\\n<p><strong>Influenced Artists:</strong> The KLF's use of cinematic samples directly influenced the work of <strong>The Future Sound of London</strong>, specifically their breakout track <strong>\\\"Papua New Guinea\\\"</strong>.</p>\\n<h3>Marketing Potential</h3>\\n<p>Unmatched for \\\"Retro-Futurism\\\" branding.</p>\", \"representation\": \"storage\"}}, \"version\": {\"number\": 2, \"minorEdit\": false}, \"history\": {\"latest\": true, \"createdBy\": {\"type\": \"known\", \"username\": \"system\", \"displayName\": \"System User\"}, \"createdDate\": \"2025-12-22T15:00:00.000Z\"}, \"link\": \"/wiki/rest/api/content/9\"}, \"10\": {\"id\": \"10\", \"type\": \"page\", \"title\": \"NMR: The KLF - Justified and Ancient\", \"spaceKey\": \"NMR\", \"status\": \"current\", \"body\": {\"storage\": {\"value\": \"<h2>New Music Research Report</h2>\\n<p><strong>Song Title:</strong> Justified & Ancient (Stand by The JAMs)</p>\\n<p><strong>Artist:</strong> The KLF featuring Tammy Wynette</p>\\n<hr />\\n<h3>Background & History</h3>\\n<p>Released in 1991, this version of the track is a collaborative effort between the KLF and American country music legend Tammy Wynette. It reached #2 in the UK and #11 in the US. The song is famous for its surrealist lyrics about \\\"Mu Mu Land\\\" and its unlikely stylistic blend of dance-pop and country.</p>\\n<h3>Cultural Context</h3>\\n<p>A prime example of the KLF's \\\"pop as performance art\\\" approach. The collaboration with Wynette was seen as a bold cross-genre experiment that bridged the gap between the Nashville establishment and the British rave scene. It remains one of the most recognizable tracks of the early 90s.</p>\\n<h3>Marketing Potential</h3>\\n<p>Excellent for \\\"Unexpected Collaboration\\\" or \\\"Genre-Bending\\\" themed campaigns. The track has a high nostalgic recognition factor and a kitschy, uplifting energy suitable for lifestyle and fashion branding.</p>\", \"representation\": \"storage\"}}, \"version\": {\"number\": 1, \"minorEdit\": false}, \"history\": {\"latest\": true, \"createdBy\": {\"type\": \"known\", \"username\": \"system\", \"displayName\": \"System User\"}, \"createdDate\": \"2025-12-22T16:00:00.000Z\"}, \"_links\": {\"self\": \"/wiki/rest/api/content/10\"}}}, \"long_task_counter\": 1, \"content_labels\": {}, \"long_tasks\": {}, \"spaces\": {\"NMR\": {\"name\": \"New Music Research\", \"description\": \"Central knowledge base for the New Music Research division. It was Bush's most successful 1980s release.</p>\\n<h3>Cultural Context</h3>\\n<p>Experienced a massive global resurgence in 2022 after being featured prominently in Season 4 of the Netflix series <em>Stranger Things</em>. It reached #1 in the UK and #3 in the US decades after its debut, introducing Bush to Gen Z.</p>\\n<h3>Marketing Potential</h3>\\n<p>High potential for \\\"Nostalgia Core\\\" branding. Produced by Bill Drummond and Jimmy Cauty.</p>\\n<h3>Cultural Context</h3>\\n<p>A landmark track of the UK Acid House and Rave movement. famously deleted from their back catalog in 1992.</p>\\n<p><strong>Strategic Connection (The Orb):</strong> There is a direct lineage between this track and <em>Little Fluffy Clouds</em> via member Jimmy Cauty.</p>\\n<p><strong>Influenced Artists:</strong> The KLF's use of cinematic samples directly influenced the work of <strong>The Future Sound of London</strong>, specifically their breakout track <strong>\\\"Papua New Guinea\\\"</strong>.</p>\\n<h3>Marketing Potential</h3>\\n<p>Unmatched for \\\"Retro-Futurism\\\" branding.</p>\", \"representation\": \"storage\"}}, \"version\": {\"number\": 2, \"minorEdit\": false}, \"history\": {\"latest\": true, \"createdBy\": {\"type\": \"known\", \"username\": \"system\", \"displayName\": \"System User\"}, \"createdDate\": \"2025-12-22T15:00:00.000Z\"}, \"link\": \"/wiki/rest/api/content/9\"}, \"10\": {\"id\": \"10\", \"type\": \"page\", \"title\": \"NMR: The KLF - Justified and Ancient\", \"spaceKey\": \"NMR\", \"status\": \"current\", \"body\": {\"storage\": {\"value\": \"<h2>New Music Research Report</h2>\\n<p><strong>Song Title:</strong> Justified & Ancient (Stand by The JAMs)</p>\\n<p><strong>Artist:</strong> The KLF featuring Tammy Wynette</p>\\n<hr />\\n<h3>Background & History</h3>\\n<p>Released in 1991, this version of the track is a collaborative effort between the KLF and American country music legend Tammy Wynette. It reached #2 in the UK and #11 in the US. The song is famous for its surrealist lyrics about \\\"Mu Mu Land\\\" and its unlikely stylistic blend of dance-pop and country.</p>\\n<h3>Cultural Context</h3>\\n<p>A prime example of the KLF's \\\"pop as performance art\\\" approach. The collaboration with Wynette was seen as a bold cross-genre experiment that bridged the gap between the Nashville establishment and the British rave scene. It remains one of the most recognizable tracks of the early 90s.</p>\\n<h3>Marketing Potential</h3>\\n<p>Excellent for \\\"Unexpected Collaboration\\\" or \\\"Genre-Bending\\\" themed campaigns. 3am Eternal\", \"spaceKey\": \"NMR\", \"status\": \"current\", \"body\": {\"storage\": {\"value\": \"<h2>New Music Research Report</h2>\\n<p><strong>Song Title:</strong> 3am Eternal (Live at the S.S.L.)</p>\\n<p><strong>Artist:</strong> The KLF</p>\\n<hr />\\n<h3>Background & History</h3>\\n<p>Originally released in 1989 as part of their \\\"Pure Trance\\\" series, the definitive \\\"Stadium House\\\" version was released in 1991. Produced by Bill Drummond and Jimmy Cauty.</p>\\n<h3>Cultural Context</h3>\\n<p>A landmark track of the UK Acid House and Rave movement. famously deleted from their back catalog in 1992.</p>\\n<p><strong>Strategic Connection (The Orb):</strong> There is a direct lineage between this track and <em>Little Fluffy Clouds</em> via member Jimmy Cauty.</p>\\n<p><strong>Influenced Artists:</strong> The KLF's use of cinematic samples directly influenced the work of <strong>The Future Sound of London</strong>, specifically their breakout track <strong>\\\"Papua New Guinea\\\"</strong>.</p>\\n<h3>Marketing Potential</h3>\\n<p>Unmatched for \\\"Retro-Futurism\\\" branding.</p>\", \"representation\": \"storage\"}}, \"version\": {\"number\": 2, \"minorEdit\": false}, \"history\": {\"latest\": true, \"createdBy\": {\"type\": \"known\", \"username\": \"system\", \"displayName\": \"System User\"}, \"createdDate\": \"2025-12-22T15:00:00.000Z\"}, \"link\": \"/wiki/rest/api/content/9\"}, \"10\": {\"id\": \"10\", \"type\": \"page\", \"title\": \"NMR: The KLF - Justified and Ancient\", \"spaceKey\": \"NMR\", \"status\": \"current\", \"body\": {\"storage\": {\"value\": \"<h2>New Music Research Report</h2>\\n<p><strong>Song Title:</strong> Justified & Ancient (Stand by The JAMs)</p>\\n<p><strong>Artist:</strong> The KLF featuring Tammy Wynette</p>\\n<hr />\\n<h3>Background & History</h3>\\n<p>Released in 1991, this version of the track is a collaborative effort between the KLF and American country music legend Tammy Wynette. It reached #2 in the UK and #11 in the US. The song is famous for its surrealist lyrics about \\\"Mu Mu Land\\\" and its unlikely stylistic blend of dance-pop and country.</p>\\n<h3>Cultural Context</h3>\\n<p>A prime example of the KLF's \\\"pop as performance art\\\" approach. The collaboration with Wynette was seen as a bold cross-genre experiment that bridged the gap between the Nashville establishment and the British rave scene. It remains one of the most recognizable tracks of the early 90s.</p>\\n<h3>Marketing Potential</h3>\\n<p>Excellent for \\\"Unexpected Collaboration\\\" or \\\"Genre-Bending\\\" themed campaigns. The track has a high nostalgic recognition factor and a kitschy, uplifting energy suitable for lifestyle and fashion branding.</p>\", \"representation\": \"storage\"}}, \"version\": {\"number\": 1, \"minorEdit\": false}, \"history\": {\"latest\": true, \"createdBy\": {\"type\": \"known\", \"username\": \"system\", \"displayName\": \"System User\"}, \"createdDate\": \"2025-12-22T16:00:00.000Z\"}, \"_links\": {\"self\": \"/wiki/rest/api/content/10\"}}}, \"long_task_counter\": 1, \"content_labels\": {}, \"long_tasks\": {}, \"spaces\": {\"NMR\": {\"name\": \"New Music Research\", \"description\": \"Central knowledge base for the New Music Research division. It was Bush's most successful 1980s release.</p>\\n<h3>Cultural Context</h3>\\n<p>Experienced a massive global resurgence in 2022 after being featured prominently in Season 4 of the Netflix series <em>Stranger Things</em>. It reached #1 in the UK and #3 in the US decades after its debut, introducing Bush to Gen Z.</p>\\n<h3>Marketing Potential</h3>\\n<p>High potential for \\\"Nostalgia Core\\\" branding. Produced by Bill Drummond and Jimmy Cauty.</p>\\n<h3>Cultural Context</h3>\\n<p>A landmark track of the UK Acid House and Rave movement. famously deleted from their back catalog in 1992.</p>\\n<p><strong>Strategic Connection (The Orb):</strong> There is a direct lineage between this track and <em>Little Fluffy Clouds</em> via member Jimmy Cauty.</p>\\n<p><strong>Influenced Artists:</strong> The KLF's use of cinematic samples directly influenced the work of <strong>The Future Sound of London</strong>, specifically their breakout track <strong>\\\"Papua New Guinea\\\"</strong>.</p>\\n<h3>Marketing Potential</h3>\\n<p>Unmatched for \\\"Retro-Futurism\\\" branding.</p>\", \"representation\": \"storage\"}}, \"version\": {\"number\": 2, \"minorEdit\": false}, \"history\": {\"latest\": true, \"createdBy\": {\"type\": \"known\", \"username\": \"system\", \"displayName\": \"System User\"}, \"createdDate\": \"2025-12-22T15:00:00.000Z\"}, \"link\": \"/wiki/rest/api/content/9\"}, \"10\": {\"id\": \"10\", \"type\": \"page\", \"title\": \"NMR: The KLF - Justified and Ancient\", \"spaceKey\": \"NMR\", \"status\": \"current\", \"body\": {\"storage\": {\"value\": \"<h2>New Music Research Report</h2>\\n<p><strong>Song Title:</strong> Justified & Ancient (Stand by The JAMs)</p>\\n<p><strong>Artist:</strong> The KLF featuring Tammy Wynette</p>\\n<hr />\\n<h3>Background & History</h3>\\n<p>Released in 1991, this version of the track is a collaborative effort between the KLF and American country music legend Tammy Wynette. It reached #2 in the UK and #11 in the US. The song is famous for its surrealist lyrics about \\\"Mu Mu Land\\\" and its unlikely stylistic blend of dance-pop and country.</p>\\n<h3>Cultural Context</h3>\\n<p>A prime example of the KLF's \\\"pop as performance art\\\" approach. The collaboration with Wynette was seen as a bold cross-genre experiment that bridged the gap between the Nashville establishment and the British rave scene. It remains one of the most recognizable tracks of the early 90s.</p>\\n<h3>Marketing Potential</h3>\\n<p>Excellent for \\\"Unexpected Collaboration\\\" or \\\"Genre-Bending\\\" themed campaigns. 3am Eternal (Live at the S.S.L.)&lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Artist:&lt;/strong&gt; The KLF&lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;hr /&gt;\\n&lt;h3&gt;Background &amp; History&lt;/h3&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;Originally released in 1989 as part of their \\&quot;Pure Trance\\&quot; series, the definitive \\&quot;Stadium House\\&quot; version was released in 1991. Produced by Bill Drummond and Jimmy Cauty.&lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;h3&gt;Cultural Context&lt;/h3&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;A landmark track of the UK Acid House and Rave movement. famously deleted from their back catalog in 1992.&lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Strategic Connection (The Orb):&lt;/strong&gt; There is a direct lineage between this track and &lt;em&gt;Little Fluffy Clouds&lt;/em&gt; via member Jimmy Cauty.&lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Influenced Artists:&lt;/strong&gt; The KLF&#x27;s use of cinematic samples directly influenced the work of &lt;strong&gt;The Future Sound of London&lt;/strong&gt;, specifically their breakout track &lt;strong&gt;\\&quot;Papua New Guinea\\&quot;&lt;/strong&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;h3&gt;Marketing Potential&lt;/h3&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;Unmatched for \\&quot;Retro-Futurism\\&quot; Running Up That Hill (A Deal with God)&lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Artist:&lt;/strong&gt; Kate Bush&lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;hr /&gt;\\n&lt;h3&gt;Background &amp; History&lt;/h3&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;Originally released in 1985 as the lead single from her fifth studio album, &lt;em&gt;Hounds of Love&lt;/em&gt;. It was Bush&#x27;s most successful 1980s release.&lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;h3&gt;Cultural Context&lt;/h3&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;Experienced a massive global resurgence in 2022 after being featured prominently in Season 4 of the Netflix series &lt;em&gt;Stranger Things&lt;/em&gt;. It reached #1 in the UK and #3 in the US decades after its debut, introducing Bush to Gen Z.&lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;h3&gt;Marketing Potential&lt;/h3&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;High potential for \\&quot;Nostalgia Core\\&quot; branding. Demonstrates the power of synchronization in streaming television to revitalize legacy catalogs.&lt;/p&gt;&quot;, &quot;representation&quot;: &quot;storage&quot;}}, &quot;version&quot;: {&quot;number&quot;: 1, &quot;minorEdit&quot;: false}, &quot;history&quot;: {&quot;latest&quot;: true, &quot;createdBy&quot;: {&quot;type&quot;: &quot;known&quot;, &quot;username&quot;: &quot;system&quot;, &quot;displayName&quot;: &quot;System User&quot;}, &quot;createdDate&quot;: &quot;2026-01-01T14:20:00.000Z&quot;}, &quot;_links&quot;: {&quot;self&quot;: &quot;/wiki/rest/api/content/4&quot;}}, &quot;5&quot;: {&quot;id&quot;: &quot;5&quot;, &quot;type&quot;: &quot;page&quot;, &quot;title&quot;: &quot;NMR: Chappell Roan - Good Luck, Babe!&quot;, &quot;spaceKey&quot;: &quot;NMR&quot;, &quot;status&quot;: &quot;current&quot;, &quot;body&quot;: {&quot;storage&quot;: {&quot;value&quot;: &quot;&lt;h2&gt;NMR: Chappell Roan - Good Luck, Babe!&lt;/h2&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Song Title:&lt;/strong&gt; Good Luck, Babe!&lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Artist:&lt;/strong&gt; Chappell Roan&lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;hr /&gt;\\n&lt;h3&gt;Background &amp; History&lt;/h3&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;Released in April 2024 as a standalone single. Produced by Dan Nigro (Olivia Rodrigo). It marks a pivotal shift in Roan&#x27;s career toward mainstream pop stardom.&lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;h3&gt;Cultural Context&lt;/h3&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;Became a \\&quot;sleeper hit\\&quot; and viral sensation on TikTok and Reels. Often cited as a defining queer pop anthem of the mid-2020s, fueled by Roan&#x27;s theatrical live performances at Coachella and Governors Ball.&lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;h3&gt;Marketing Potential&lt;/h3&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;Ideal for \\&quot;Main Character Energy\\&quot; campaigns. Strong demographic alignment with LGBTQ+ youth and high engagement in fan-driven social media trends.&lt;/p&gt;&quot;, &quot;representation&quot;: &quot;storage&quot;}}, &quot;version&quot;: {&quot;number&quot;: 1, &quot;minorEdit&quot;: false}, &quot;history&quot;: {&quot;latest&quot;: true, &quot;createdBy&quot;: {&quot;type&quot;: &quot;known&quot;, &quot;username&quot;: &quot;system&quot;, &quot;displayName&quot;: &quot;System User&quot;}, &quot;createdDate&quot;: &quot;2026-01-01T14:20:00.000Z&quot;}, &quot;_links&quot;: {&quot;self&quot;: &quot;/wiki/rest/api/content/5&quot;}}, &quot;6&quot;: {&quot;id&quot;: &quot;6&quot;, &quot;type&quot;: &quot;page&quot;, &quot;title&quot;: &quot;Weekly Research: Dec 15, 2025&quot;, &quot;spaceKey&quot;: &quot;NMR&quot;, &quot;status&quot;: &quot;current&quot;, &quot;body&quot;: {&quot;storage&quot;: {&quot;value&quot;: &quot;&lt;h1&gt;Weekly Research: Dec 15, 2025&lt;/h1&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;Lead Researcher: Julian Vane&lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;hr /&gt;\\n&lt;h2&gt;Track List&lt;/h2&gt;\\n&lt;ol&gt;\\n&lt;li&gt;NMR: Lorde -
